bib_record.title: Measurement of Absolute Fission Yields in the Fast Neutron-Induced Fission of Actinides: 238U, 237Np, 238Pu, 240Pu, 243Am, and 244Cm by  Track-Etch-cum-Gamma Spectrometry

free_txt: The data for 240Pu and 241Am
were published.
part of the data on the fast
neutron-induced fission of 238U has been published.
A preliminary report of this work has been published
in Proc. Int. Seminar Enhanced Utilization
and Reactors, Bombay, India, March 11-15, 1996
The targets were covered with 0.75-mu-m-thick superpure
aluminum foil and then with a 75-mu-m-thick Lexan foil,
which acted as a catcher foil to collect the recoiling
fission products during neutron irradiation of the
target. The thin aluminum foil prevented self-transfer
of the target activity to the Lexan catcher foil. It
was then wrapped with another piece of 0.0025-cm-thick
aluminum foil. About 200 mu-l of a dilute solution of
known concentration of 238U (1.42 mg/ml),
240Pu (5.07 mu-g/ml), 243Am (26.85 mu-g/ml), and
244Cm (0.202 mu-g/ml) were taken in polypropylene tubes
approx.4 cm long and with a 3-mm inner diameter with an
open cut at one end. Two small strips of mica or Lexan
track detectors were put into the solution, and the
polypropylene tubes were then heat sealed. The targets
and the sealed polypropylene tubes were wrapped with
1-mm-thick cadmium foils and then double sealed in
alkathene bags.
For short-lived fission products in the case of 238U
and 237Np, approx. 200 ml of 238U (30.01 mg/ml) and
237Np (1.228 mg/ml) in the form of nitrate solutions
along with a strip of Lexan or mica track detector seal
in a polypropylene tube were covered with 1-mm-thick
cadmium foil and again sealed in alkathene bags.
Lexa or mica strip for collection of fission
products
The products were analyzed by gamma spectrometry
at a fixed geometry of an energy- and efficiency-
calibrated 80- or 120-cm3 high-purity germanium
detector coupled to a PC-based 4K channel analyzer.
The purity of the targets and the amounts were
assayed and checked by alpha spectrometry using a
silicon surface barrier detector connected to a
PC-based 4K. channel analyzer.
Systematic errors due to uncertainties in:
the irradiation time (2%);
detector efficiency calibration (3%);
half-lives of fission products (1%);
and gamma-ray abundance, which shows the largest
variation in the literature.
The random error in the observed
activity due to:
counting statistics, determined by
accumulating the data for optimum time periods, is
estimated to be less than 5%, depending on the
half-life of the nuclide of interest.
The random error in the calculation of the
total number of fissions, which can arise from the
uncertainties in the measurement of:
the track density (3%),
track registration efficiency (1%),
the weight (amount) of the fissile material in
the target and in the dilute solution (0.5%).
Besides these, one additional source of random error of
3% is estimated in the chemical yield determination
in the case of the radiochemically separated samples.
The absolute fission yields of various
fission products were determined using radiochemical
and gamma spectrometric techniques in combination with
the track-etch method.
T1/2(149Pm)=53 hr according to ENSDF
The statistical fluctuations of the mean
value from two to four determinations except in those
few cases where only single measurements could be done.
The target assemblies were irradiated
for 30 min to 7 hr in a fixed water-moderated, highly
enriched uranium-fueled swimming pool reactor APSARA
at a flux of 10**11 n/cm2/s.
For short-lived fission products the U target was
irradiated for 5 min in the same position.
Epi-cadmium spectrum
A known amount (approx.5 mg) of the oxide of 238U
of purity 99.9997% was carefully weighed into a small
piece (1 cm X 1 cm) of 0.0025-cm-thick superpure
aluminum foil and folded into a small packet.
